item.title: Canada launched major gun reforms in 2020 after its deadliest mass shooting.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Tim Krochak/Reuters
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial in Portapique, Nova Scotia, for the victims of Canada’s deadliest mass shooting in 2020.

item.title: A Peaceful Mountain Town in Western Canada Is Shaken by Deadly Shooting
item.description: Tumbler Ridge sits at the foothills of the Rocky Mountains in northeastern British Columbia, and is surrounded by expansive mountain ranges and a geological park.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Google

item.title: 9 Killed and 25 Injured in Shootings at School and Home in British Columbia
item.description: Police say the suspected shooter died of a self-inflicted injury after the shooting in Tumbler Ridge, a remote community.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado

item.title: Guatemala to End Use of Cuban Doctors, Under U.S. Pressure
item.description: The program, nearly 30 years old, had allowed Cuban medical workers to fill critical needs in Guatemala, while reaping income for Cuba.
item.dc:creator: Jody García and James Wagner
item.media:credit: Eitan Abramovich/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Cuban doctor and a patient in San Mateo, Guatemala, in 2009. Cuba’s medical brigade of health care workers has been a fixture in Guatemala for nearly 30 years.

item.title: Mexican Cartel’s Seized Ammunition Is Traced to U.S. Army Plant
item.description: About 137,000 .50-caliber rounds have been seized since 2012, and of those, 47 percent came from a plant in Kansas City, Mo., Mexico’s defense secretary said.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: A police officer in Villa Unión, Mexico, with a .50-caliber cartridge. Mexico’s defense secretary said that about 137,000 .50-caliber rounds had been seized since 2012.

item.title: Before Trump Blasted U.S.-Canada Bridge, Owner of Competing Span Lobbied Administration
item.description: A Detroit billionaire met with Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary, hours before President Trump said he would block the opening of a new bridge connecting Detroit to Canada, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Gordie Howe International Bridge (Detroit, Mich and Windsor, Ontario)
item.media:credit: Dax Melmer/Reuters
item.media:description: President Trump said on Monday he would block the opening of the Gordie Howe International Bridge, currently under construction to link Detroit with Windsor, Ontario.

item.title: What to Know About Canada’s New Bridge to the U.S. That Trump Hates
item.description: President Trump’s threat to block the opening of the new crossing is the latest in a long string of challenges for the project.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Gordie Howe International Bridge, which is expected to open this year, will connect Windsor, Ontario, and Detroit.

item.title: Trump’s Threats to Cuba’s Oil Suppliers Put Mexico in a Bind
item.description: The longstanding alliance between Cuba and Mexico is under mounting pressure from the United States, forcing President Claudia Sheinbaum into a precarious balancing act.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico now must juggle two competing priorities: honoring long‑standing ties to Havana while navigating an essential but increasingly strained relationship with Washington.

item.title: Visiting Riviera Nayarit in Mexico
item.description: A budget-friendly stretch of coastal towns in Mexico offers a relaxing antidote to hot spots like Cancún and Puerto Vallarta.
item.dc:creator: Colleen Creamer and César Rodríguez

item.title: Nicaragua Blocks a Route from Cuba to the U.S.
item.description: The Trump administration has criticized Nicaragua for serving as an illegal immigration pathway to the United States.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Norlys Perez/Reuters
item.media:description: Cubans lining up outside the Nicaraguan Embassy in Havana on Monday, after Nicaragua ended visa-free entry for Cuban citizens.

item.title: Air Canada and WestJet Cancel Flights to Cuba Over Jet Fuel Shortage
item.description: The Trump administration’s crackdown on oil shipments to Cuba is beginning to wreak havoc on the Caribbean island’s travel industry.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Air Canada planes at Vancouver International Airport. The airline announced on Monday that it had suspended its 16 flights per week to four Cuban cities. Canada is the top source of tourists to Cuba.

item.title: Venezuela Frees Key Opposition Figures, Then Rearrests One
item.description: Hours after at least 35 political prisoners were released, one of the most prominent was apparently back in custody, raising doubts about the government’s direction and control.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times

item.title: Cuba’s Communist Government Has Lasted 67 Years. Will It Fall Under Trump?
item.description: The Trump administration, which has tightened the U.S. chokehold on Cuba by cutting off foreign oil, is betting that this is the Cuban communist revolution’s last year.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and David C. Adams
item.media:credit: Jack Manning/The New York Times
item.media:description: Fidel Castro, who led Cuba from the 1959 revolution until he formally stepped down in 2008, speaking in Santa Maria Del Mar in 1964.

item.title: Trump’s Oil Grab in Venezuela Shatters an American Taboo
item.description: U.S. presidents have long been accused of plotting to control foreign oil. But President Trump has asserted a U.S. right to take it.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venezuela’s Cardon oil refinery. Critics say President Trump’s plan for the country’s oil industry revives bitter memories of colonial exploitation and flagrantly violates international law.

item.title: 6 Fishermen Reel In a 244-Pound Atlantic Halibut, Setting a Local Record
item.description: The fish, hooked as part of a study on the halibut population around the Ha! Ha! Bay in the Canadian province of Quebec, measured more than 6.5 feet long, researchers said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker

item.title: At the Olympics, the Canada-U.S. Hockey Rivalry Heats Up
item.description: Beating America has always felt good, especially on the ice. Since President Trump began issuing tariffs and threats against Canada, sports feels extra personal.
item.dc:creator: Shawna Richer
item.media:credit: Cameron Spencer/Getty Images
item.media:description: Canadian athletes during the opening ceremony at Livigno Snow Park on Friday.

item.title: Haiti Reaches ‘Full Crisis’ as Transition Government Expires
item.description: The tenure of a presidential council that has been running Haiti expires on Saturday. It’s unclear what will come next.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles, David C. Adams and André Paultre
item.media:credit: Clarens Siffroy/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A view from inside an armored police vehicle showing cars burned by armed gangs and used as a barricade on a deserted street Port-au-Prince, Haiti, last month.

item.title: China Reverses Death Sentence for Canadian in a Small Win for Carney
item.description: The ruling by China’s highest court followed a recent meeting between China and Canada’s top leaders that led to a thaw in the two countries’ relations.
item.dc:creator: Lily Kuo
item.media:credit: Intermediate Peoples' Court of Dalian, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Robert Lloyd Schellenberg in 2019 during his retrial on drug-trafficking charges in a court in Dalian, China.

item.title: Argentina and U.S. Sign Sweeping Trade Deal as Alliance Deepens
item.description: The deal reduces reciprocal tariffs and expands quotas for key trading goods, including Argentine beef — a flashpoint for American ranchers.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump with President Javier Milei of Argentina at the White House in October.

item.title: Toronto Police Charged in Sweeping Drug and Corruption Case
item.description: After hit men targeted the home of a prison manager in June, investigators say, the schemes of a criminal network involving the police unraveled.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Jon Blacker/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: From left, Chief Myron Demkiw of the Toronto police, Chief Jim MacSween and Deputy Chief Ryan Hogan of the York Regional Police at a news conference on Thursday in Aurora, Ontario.

item.title: Mayor of Tequila, Mexico, Is Accused of Shaking Down Tequila Companies
item.description: The mayor of the city that is the birthplace of the bottled spirit is the latest official to be arrested as Mexico targets cartel-related corruption.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Lindsay Lauckner Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Blue agave, grown for tequila, in Jalisco state, Mexico.

item.title: Carney Increases E.V. Investments as Trump’s Trade Policy Disrupts Canada’s Auto Industry
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney announced several measures Thursday aimed at making Canada a global leader in electric vehicles and rescuing an industry ravaged by U.S. trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Eduardo Lima/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada, right, visiting an auto parts plant on Thursday in Woodbridge, Ontario.

item.title: Rare Deep-Sea Giant Phantom Jellyfish Sighting Is Recorded on Video
item.description: During a dive off Argentina, scientists documented a rare jellyfish discovered a little over a century ago and seldom seen since, as well as the fish that keep it company.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil

item.title: Venezuela Said to Detain Maduro Allies Targeted by the U.S.
item.description: The questioning of the politically connected businessmen, Raúl Gorrín and Alex Saab, signaled deepening cooperation between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Annie Correal

item.title: Canada’s Tate McRae Roots for Team USA in New Olympics Ad
item.description: Tate McRae’s promotional video for NBC, in which she name checks Team USA athletes, has drawn the ire of some Canadians as the country’s relationship with the United States hits new lows.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Monica Schipper/Getty Images
item.media:description: Tate McRae in December in Los Angeles.

item.title: ‘Things Have Not Changed’: What ‘Heated Rivalry’ Gets Right About Men’s Sports
item.description: The show, about a romance between two closeted pro hockey players, is a surprise hit. But its popularity underscores how little has changed in the hypermasculine world of men’s professional sports.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb

item.title: Here’s How the U.S. Accepted Danish Control of Greenland 100 Years Ago.
item.description: In 1917, the United States bought Caribbean islands from Denmark and agreed to respect Denmark’s hold over Greenland. The deal resurfaced with President Trump’s recent threats to seize Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue commemorating Hans Egede, a Danish missionary who founded Nuuk, the capital of Greenland, in the 18th century, overlooking the city last year.
